Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Learned so much about so many different topics from pregnancy to sexual response to birth to ethics to contraception to genetics
I learned a lot of concepts relating to reproduction in both males and females, from biological mechanisms to large-scale implications.
Definitely one of the most useful and relevant courses Ive taken at yale.
I learned all about male and female reproduction. We mainly focused on female reproduction and went through the entire life cycle, from fetus to menopause.
I learned about a wide variety of topics related to reproductive biology, from the molecular/genetic level to clinical care.
lots of info on reproduction
I learned about all areas of human reproduction from experts across varying fields.
I learned an insane amount about reproduction. Also how to think critically about scientific papers.
I learned about the anatomy and physiology associated with reproductive systems, as well as embryonic development, pregnancy, menstruation, and other reproductively-relevant topics.
Female reproductive system, HP-axes, taking med school-esque classes.
Reproductive biology
A lot of reproductive biology knowledge.
Reproductive biology.
Learned about reproductive biology
I not only learned so much about reproduction, but also gained valuable insights from the various physicians who came to lecture the course.

I learned a lot about the reproduction and biology behind it. I also didn't realize how little sexual/reproductive health education in middle and high school actually teaches you, so I thought this was a great fundamental course that more students should take.
A lot of knowledge about reproduction. No skills or insights.
The biology of reproduction is fascinating! I learned a ton about hormone signaling and how it effects everything to do with reproduction.
I gained knowledge of everything concerning reproduction. It began with the formation of eggs and sperm and continued all the way through menopause.
the biology behind many processes involved in reproduction-- from spermatogenesis and oogenesis to puberty to pregnancy to infertility interventions and menopause.
I learned about the human reproductive system and hormonal regulation of the human reproductive system.
I learned about the biology behind fertility, assisted reproductive technology, reproduction, fetal development, sexual development, and endocrinology.
I learned a ton about reproduction, development, and sexual disorders throughout this class.
I learned about various aspects of reproduction varying from physiological concepts to cellular mechanisms.
None
I learned a lot about the science of reproduction, as well as how to adapt to many different lecturers.
I learned about the biological processes involved in reproduction.
I gained a vast knowledge of many aspects of reproductive biology  ranging from reproductive systems to development and ethics.
Reproductive system, knowing how the placenta works and fetus develops, hormonal regulation, how fetus maipulates the mother's metabolic processes to survive during pregnancy
I developed a lot of insight into how the reproductive systems work in the human body.
This course was really interesting in terms of content but the different lecturers made it difficult to understand everything.
I learned a lot about the biology of the reproductive system, and about medical applications of this.
This course was very interesting to learn about all aspects of reproduction.
Withdrew
I learned a lot about the development of humans and what can go wrong along the way.

Strengths: the exams were fair, the review sessions were helpful, the professors/TAs listened to use when we said we wanted to use Piazza to ask questions

Weaknesses: because there were so many lecturers (almost every class session has a different one), I felt like it was a little disjointed. I think the professors need to communicate with each other more because sometimes they kept repeating the same things over and over again or they didn't know how much we'd learned and had to keep asking us "have you learned this?"
Just a truly great course. The exams can be a little tricky so study really hard for them but other than that theres no work for the class.
I thought the material was interesting. I also liked how every lecture was from a different professor, as it allowed for more diverse teaching backgrounds and information.

It was clear that many profs didnt update the slides from years past. In many cases, this was especially egregious (demographic data only from 2008, for example)

There was a highly variable instructor quality. The first test was also pretty hard considering that some of the professors didnt do as good of a job. also, some professors got to ask more questions on exams per lecture, which felt unfair.

I thought it was ridiculous that we had to attend an extra section if we were an MCDB major. #1, this was not on the syllabus, which was an absurd oversight. #2, how did we get the same credit for putting in a lot more work? #3, the times were incredibly inconvenient (7pm on Monday and Tuesday) and there was no variability, so a lot of us had to miss senior events and things like that because of poor planning.

The tests were pretty challenging and often required knowledge of very nit picky details. It would be nice to have some other assignments to factor into your grade as opposed to just three big exams. I did appreciate the exams being non-cumulative but they were still pretty difficult. I also liked having a new lecturer every class and most of them were pretty good.

Strengths: many interesting lectures accessible to people from a variety of backgrounds (biology, public health, non-STEM). Professors who specialize in the particular topic of the day give the lectures. I liked that lessons were applicable to everyday life.

Weaknesses: some of the guest instructors were not good lecturers. I understand the desire to have speakers who are (in many cases) very well known for their contributions to a particular topic, but if they can't put together a presentation that is suitable for undergraduates new to the field, I'd rather have a different teacher explain the material to us. Additionally, after the first exam, it seemed that biology took a backseat in the course--I think a greater emphasis on mechanisms would be helpful. Moreover, exams were multiple choice, which I didn't feel really tested student knowledge in-depth. It would be nice to have TAs for the course who actually specialize in reproductive biology instead of those who work in other areas of biology who may not know this course's material as well.
great material, difference in quality between lecturers, some redundancy
I liked having different lecturers, but it was challenging to adjust to a new teaching style three times a week. Some of the lecturers were more interesting than others.

I think that overall the lecturing format with new teachers each time lecturing on their subject of interest was great. I do think that some of the professors were much weaker than others. The HPA and Sexual response lectures were particularly weak. 
I thought that the subject matter was fascinating.

A strength is that the content was extremely interesting, and it was nice to have some themes (e.g. cycle of estrogen/progesterone in women) to come back to throughout the course. A weakness is that some professors didn't seem prepared or weren't the clearest lecturersit would be a good idea to have student feedback at the end of the course for this aspect to modify the speaker list slightly from year to year.

Strengths: Outside of (three) midterms, absolutely zero work. Enjoyable and digestible material overall. Some professors were great. Weaknesses: Some professors were really not great. Midterms were very petty - you were expected to memorise every last detail of the most obscure slides. Biggest weakness were the TAs, they were really useless and lead the most pointless review sessions. Absolutely no indication of how the class is graded also (which is worrisome given that the averages are generally fairly high).

It was very disorganized. There was no common thread between lectures with a lot of detailed excess information that made it hard to parse through what was relevant and not. The discussion section, although interesting, provided did not help to reinforce the key concepts in class. Instead of reviewing papers, an overview of the weekly information would be much more helpful.
Having the course taught by many different lecturers was at times great, but overall inconsistent and left me feeling unsatisfied.

This course needs to be improved. It is very incoherent, and the lectures are not linked together well at all, since they are ALL taught by guest lecturers. There are literally no tools given for you to succeed. The TAs in the class also have no idea what they are doing. Overall a very poorly organized and taught course.

I felt that the number of professors, while engaging, made it difficult to have consistent conversations particularly around gender and sexuality - at times, the language lecturers used felt transphobic and alienating.

I found it difficult to have so many different lecturers, many of whom seemed to be presenting on slide shows and materials that they themselves had not prepared, and therefore were not as effective as teaching to others.

Weaknesses: very disorganized, lecturers varied in quality, very hard to predict how to study for exams because the questions are compiled by so many different people
Strengths: only three exams/chill class
This course is extremely relevant and super engaging.

Strengths: There were some really great lecturers that outweighed the bad ones that we had. Also, I think the exams were relatively fair. 

Weaknesses: Requiring sections for MCDB majors is a weakness of this course because the engagement with the material really varies across the class and because people had to manage both studying for the midterm and reading extra papers during midterm weeks, this placed added stress on students. Often times, discussion lagged in section because the papers and sometimes the TA was not engaged in the material.

Terribly disjointed lectures, a different faculty member for almost every lecture, a lot of overlapping repetitive material, half of the faculty seem to have no bearing on public speaking and lecturing whatsoever.

The strength of the course is that there is no work outside of the three midterms, so it's a relatively stress-free STEM class with really interesting content. The course could be improved by having more consistency across guest speakers (a lot of material was repeated), and by having practice exams/review terms available. Some of the questions on the test were also poorly worded and were not clearly taught in the lecture. For a class in which your grade is entirely based on how you do on three midterms, this can be really frustrating.

Ensure that all the speakers have current slides uploaded before class. Try to encourage the professors to include more information on the slides rather than just speaking everything to the class. It can be hard for students to keep up and retain all the information. Also, be more forthcoming about how grading works and how the class works in general.

strength: interesting and informative topics, learning about yourself, having experts in different fields 
weakness: lack of uniformity across lectures (due to different teaching styles)

One weakness is that, at times, it seemed as though the lectures were not well-coordinated with each other and covered overlapping material in different ways. One strength is that it was interesting getting perspectives from various different lecturers.

The content itself was fascinating but there was high variability in the quality of lecturer. Some lectures were fabulous (ex: Professor Kankel) and others were disorganized and unfocused (ex: Professor Ratner). This made it hard to engage with the material each day.
I thought this was a great course! I loved hearing different lecturers speak in their areas of expertise. Overall this was a ton of fun, and I learned a lot!

I think the strength of this class is that the powerpoints are uploaded to canvas, but I think there is an issue with tag teaming to teach the class. Way too much material gets crammed into 1 lecture day and in to the entire semester, there is little time to be engaged and ask questions, and not all the professors are equally good at teaching.
The professors teaching the different lectures do not coordinate, so there is a lot of overlap of material and not a good understanding of what the students have already been taught.

Difficult to take notes because you have to deal with a different lecturer every class. At the same time, it's nice to learn from people who have devoted their lives to the focused area that they teach in their specific lecture.

I enjoyed that some of the lecturers incorporated clinical relevance to the biology that we were learning.
One weakness was that I felt that the midterms emphasized concepts that, while they were on the slides, were less heavily emphasized by the lecturers. Additionally, in the beginning  of the semester, it was difficult to follow along at times because we had different lecturers every class, but I thought that as lectures progressed, it was easier to piece together the concepts we were learning from previous lectures.

I think that there was a bit of dissonance given that nearly each lecture was taught by someone else. One strength was that the topics did connect but the various lecturers weren't aware of what others already taught us, which made it redundant at times.

Strength - multiple professors who were genuinely passionate about the specific topics they were teaching, nice TAs
Weakness - a lot of information and it wasn't that clear what we needed to know for the tests

I like that there are several professors for the class but I think that sections can be handled a little more effectively. While I appreciate the book club style section, I think we would have benefitted from a section where we went over the material from class.
I didn't like that there were different lecturers.

I think it was nice that some lecturers re-emphasized central components of the course that had already been taught, but there could have been more continuity/organization among the various lecturers.
This course was very well taught, but some lectures did not feel as engaging as others
Withdrew

The course covers a lot of interesting topics. One weakness would be that it can be a bit repetitive at times. Also, there is a mandatory section for majors, but the information in the papers isn't specifically on tests in a detailed manner so it just felt like a waste of time.
Please do not take this class if you are not a MCDB major. It was incredibly difficult.

Absolutely. Im an MCDB major but I convinced two of my Econ friends to Credit/D the class and they said it was one the easier Credit/Ds they have taken. Its a super interesting class and they both enjoyed taking it. I recommend it for anyone, even non-science majors. Its either a super easy Credit/D or a super low workload class with heavy studying 3 times all semester if you want a good grade.
I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in learning more about the biology of reproduction in both males and females.
yes! Definitely one of the most useful and relevant courses Ive taken at yale.
Yes, I would recommend it. I'm not an MCDB major and I still got a lot out of it.

Yes, this is an interesting biology course that encompasses a broad range of topics related to reproduction. The course grade is the result of three multiple-choice exams, which were generally reasonable and fair. Caveat: this course is taught by a different professor each class. Many are excellent, but some are not. In order to take this course, you must be willing to accept a wide variety of lecture styles, content, preparation, and presentations.
yes! lots of interesting material, not hard to keep up with, you'll learn a lot nevertheless
Yes. Only if they have a strong science background, however. I think that the class would be difficult for people who come in without prior knowledge.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. Repro bio was super interesting and engaging. I feel like I learned so much. The workload is really manageable and the structure of the course was great (three non-cumulative exams). Overall, I really enjoyed the class!

I would. I found it really interesting to learn about this particular aspect of biology, which isn't emphasized in other courses at Yale. Of course, this is a topic that's relevant for all of us, and I think everyone should at least have a basic understanding of the biology of reproduction.

If you need an easy Bio/Neuro/Sc credit, then yes! It really is no work at all. FAIR WARNING: Make sure you go to every lecture, it'll hurt you later when studying. Make sure you give yourself enough time to study for the midterms (three/four days before is good) as everyone does well and it's definitely possible to get 95%+ scores.
If they needed an MCDB credit only.
Only if they are very, very interested in the material.
Yes.
No, unless you are prepared to try to piece together everything that you are learning by yourself. The class is poorly taught.
The content is interesting but as I said before, some of the lecturers speak about gender and sexuality in really essentialist terms.

Maybe. I was very much interested in the topic and therefore wanted to learn about it, however much of the material was taught insensitively, and I did not find the caliber of the teachers to meet my expectations in most regards.

I'm an MCDB junior who took this course and it was horrible. It was disorganized, the exams questions were arbitrary, important concepts were not represented on the multiple choice exams, and it wasn't clear how to best study for the exams. MCDB classes usually have open ended/short answer questions, but this class's multiple choice exams required you to know the most nit picky random details to do well

I would definitely recommend this to other MCDB majors. It's one of the first courses where I didn't feel pressured to learn all of the intricacies of the material and could actually appreciate what the subject was about.
Not really if you are looking for intellectual stimulation. This is pretty much a gut, memorize-and-regurgitate type class. No intellectual thinking or problem solving required whatsoever.

I would recommend it as a fifth class, but don't underestimate how much work it is to prepare for the midterms. If you don't do well on a test there's also relatively little you can do to redeem your grade.

I would only recommend this course if the other student is willing to put up with a messy teaching style. The information was interesting and important, however the lectures and guest speakers were all over the place.
Yes, if they need an engaging and challenging science credit for non-MCDB majors.
Yes, it is a very interesting topic and provides a good introduction to various issues and aspects of reproductive biology.
Yes, the content itself was fascinating and the workload very managable.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student interested in the material. I loved the lectures and found going to class to be a lot of fun!

I think this is a fine course to take but I wouldn't necessarily recommend it. When I took the class I thought it would be an interesting yet more lax course to take in MCDB. I was wrong, the exams were unnecessarily tricky and I dont think they really tested what we learned.

Good class with interesting material. Pretty easy fifth class because there was zero homework and the three exams (no final) are all multiple choice / one sentence answers. Would not recommend as a science credit to people with little bio experience because there were a lot of concepts that were not touched upon but you were expected to have background in.
Yes I would recommend this course to another student. I enjoyed the emphasis on clinical relevance in some of the lectures that we had. There was low workload.

Yes, it is quite interesting and I love the fact that you get to meet so many professors in a field where things are still being discovered and explored. It was really cool to have professors come who were literally in our positions years ago and did not know the things they do now about their field because so much has been discovered since then.
Yes! I loved this course and the pretty low workload made this a class one where I could enjoy the material without feeling too stressed.
I would recommend it if you need a science credit but it is a little challenging if you don't have a basic understanding of biology.

I loved sitting in this class and listening to lectures. It was a relatively low-key and non-stressful learning environment, and there was only work prior to each midterm, which were all fine as long as you attended lecture and studied a decent amount. I'd highly recommend this course to another student. It reaffirmed by interest in medicine.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is very interesting.
Yeah. It's interesting. The lecturers aren't all great though so the class can be boring at times.
